com.fasterxml.util.membuf
Class MemBuffer

java.lang.Object
  com.fasterxml.util.membuf.MemBuffer

public class MemBuffer
extends Object

Actual memory queue implementation, which uses set of Segments as virtual ring buffer. Number of segments used is bound by minimum and maximum amounts, which defines minimim and maximum memory usage. Memory usage is relatively easy to estimate since data is stored as byte sequences and almost all memory is simply used by allocated ByteBuffers.

Access to queue is fully synchronized, since parts will have to be anyway (updating of stats, pointers), and since all real-world use cases will need some level of synchronization anyway, even with just single producer and consumer. If it turns out that there are bottlenecks that could be avoided with more granular (or external) locking, this design can be revisited.

Author:
Tatu Saloranta

Field Detail

_segmentAllocator

protected final SegmentAllocator _segmentAllocator
Object that is used for allocating physical segments, and to whom segments are released after use.

_segmentSize

protected final int _segmentSize
Size of individual segments.

_maxSegmentsForReuse

protected final int _maxSegmentsForReuse
Smallest number of segments to allocate. This defines the smallest physical size of the queue, such that queue will never shrink beyond this setting. Lowest allowed minimum size is 2, since head and tail of the queue must reside on different segments (to allow expansion)

_maxSegmentsToAllocate

protected final int _maxSegmentsToAllocate
Maximum number of segments to allocate. This defines maximum physical size of the queue.

_head

protected Segment _head
Head refers to the segment in which appends are done, which is the last segment allocated. It may be same as _tail. Note that this is the end of the logical chain starting from _tail.

_tail

protected Segment _tail
Tail refers to the segment from which read are done, which is the oldest segment allocated. It may be same as _head. Can be used for traversing all in-use segments.

_usedSegmentsCount

protected int _usedSegmentsCount
Number of segments reachable via linked list starting from _tail

_entryCount

protected int _entryCount
Number of entries stored in this buffer.

_totalPayloadLength

protected long _totalPayloadLength
Number of bytes stored in all appended entries.

_nextEntryLength

protected int _nextEntryLength
Length of the next entry, if known; -1 if not yet known.

_firstFreeSegment

protected Segment _firstFreeSegment
Most recently released segment that we hold on to for possible reuse. Only up to _maxSegmentsForReuse may be stored for reuse; others will be handed back to the allocator.

_freeSegmentCount

protected int _freeSegmentCount
Number of segments reachable via _firstFreeSegment; less than equal to _maxSegmentsToAllocate.

_lengthPrefixBuffer

protected final byte[] _lengthPrefixBuffer
Length prefix is between one and five bytes long, to encode int32 as VInt (most-significant-byte first), where last byte is indicated by set sign bit.

Constructor Detail

MemBuffer

public MemBuffer(SegmentAllocator allocator,
                 int minSegmentsToAllocate,
                 int maxSegmentsToAllocate,
                 Segment initialSegments)
Parameters:
allocator - Allocator used for allocating underlying segments
minSegmentsToAllocate - Maximum number of segments to hold on to (for reuse) after being released. Increases minimum memory usage but can improve performance by avoiding unnecessary re-allocation; and also guarantees that buffer always has at least this much storage capacity.
maxSegmentsToAllocate - Maximum number of segments that can be allocated for this buffer: limits maximum capacity and memory usage
initialSegments - Chain of pre-allocated segments, containing _maxSegmentsForReuse segments that are allocated to ensure that there is always specified minimum capacity available
Method Detail

getEntryCount

public int getEntryCount()
Method for checking how many entries are buffered in this buffer currently.

isEmpty

public boolean isEmpty()

getSegmentCount

public int getSegmentCount()
Method for checking how many segments are currently used for storing data (not including segments that may be retained for reuse but do not contain data)

getMaximumAvailableSpace

public long getMaximumAvailableSpace()
Method for checking what would be the maximum available space available for appending more entries. Since there is per-entry overhead (length prefix of at least one and at most five bytes), this is not all available for entries, but gives an approximate idea of that amount.

getTotalPayloadLength

public long getTotalPayloadLength()
Method for checking total amount of payload buffered in this buffer. This does not include entry metadata (length prefixes).

appendEntry

public final void appendEntry(byte[] data)

appendEntry

public void appendEntry(byte[] data,
                        int dataOffset,
                        int dataLength)

tryAppendEntry

public final boolean tryAppendEntry(byte[] data)

tryAppendEntry

public boolean tryAppendEntry(byte[] data,
                              int dataOffset,
                              int dataLength)

_doAppendChunked

protected void _doAppendChunked(byte[] buffer,
                                int offset,
                                int length)
Helper method that handles append when contents may need to be split across multiple segments.

_reuseFree

protected final Segment _reuseFree()
Helper method for reusing a segment from free-segments list. Caller must guarantee there is such a segment available; this is done in advance to achieve atomicity of multi-segment-allocation.

getNextEntryLength

public int getNextEntryLength()
Method that will check size of the next entry, if buffer has entries; returns size in bytes if there is at least one entry, or -1 if buffer is empty.

getNextEntry

public byte[] getNextEntry()
                    throws InterruptedException
Method for reading and removing next available entry from buffer. If no entry is available, will block to wait for more data.

Throws:
InterruptedException

getNextEntryIfAvailable

public byte[] getNextEntryIfAvailable()
Method that will read, remove and return next entry, if one is available; or return null if not.

getNextEntry

public byte[] getNextEntry(long timeoutMsecs)
                    throws InterruptedException
Method to get (and remove) next entry from the buffer, if one is available. If buffer is empty, may wait up to specified amount of time for new data to arrive.

Parameters:
timeoutMsecs - Amount of time to wait for more data if buffer is empty, if non-zero positive number; if zero or negative number, will return immediately
Returns:
Next entry from buffer, if one was available either immediately or before waiting for full timeout; or null if no entry became available
Throws:
InterruptedException

waitForNextEntry

public void waitForNextEntry()
                      throws InterruptedException
Method that can be called to wait until there is at least one entry available for reading.

Note that it is possible to have a race condition if there are multiple readers, such that even if this method returns, following read could fail/block (when another reader thread manages to thread before current thread reads next entry); this method can only be used to guarantee data for single-threaded reads, although it may work as an optimization for multiple reader case as well.

Throws:
InterruptedException

waitForNextEntry

public void waitForNextEntry(long maxWaitMsecs)
                      throws InterruptedException
Throws:
InterruptedException
